reviews.review_title: Is it legal for a movie to be this numbingly boring and still be labeled a thriller?

Sure, people come to Netflix for the Coen Brothers or for Better Call Saul and maybe that's how Netflix justifies pumping out drivel like this thing but, on the other hand, I'd be willing to bet that movies like this drive away as many subscribers as Better Call Saul attracts.

So I just watched this film, I found it to be excruciatingly slow, the story is about this author who hires a nanny to look after her kids.
But the film goes in and out of so called weird dream squences, where there's lots of steamy sexy scenes between the author and the nanny Grace. Who is Grace? And what's her background.?Mary the author finally gets over her writers block and begins to write her book.
Some parts of this film reminded me of The Hand That Rocks The Cradle.
Sadly, there's no real substance in this film to really gather momentum or the viewers attention. The only time it got abit interesting was after Elaine , Mary's best friend was murdered. The story and acting picks up a little then. Overall, this film was too long, when it didn't need to be. The acting wasn't all that good either, the plot was way too over stretched and the story line and script was quite boring.

Did she just feel like walking home? What the heck were the couple fighting about?? That argument came out of nowhere, referred to things that had never been mentioned before, and completely made no sense. I thought maybe I had memory loss too, because I must have forgotten the part where they explained this. What kind of parent has no idea how old their nanny is? Isn't this information people normally ask before hiring a stranger to look after their children? What the heck is with very loudly and casually discussing your fantasies of having sex with your -probably underage- nanny with your friend- who is also your psychiatrist!- at the gym?? This is not a thing that happens. This may be the most nonsense we have ever seen crammed into one movie. One extra star for KD dancing to Concrete Blonde:)

reviews.review_title: Once again a movie that spreads misinformation by claiming DID/schizophrenia = killer, disappointing
reviews.content: I was intrigued by the idea of the movie at first but the further it got, the worse it got. In the end it is revealed that Grace is traumatized and therefore "of course" becomes an insane killer. I am genuinely angry that mental illnesses like schizophrenia and DID keep getting portrayed like something that makes a person dangerous. This kind of "person ends up hurting others"-stuff happens extremely rarely and people who suffer from these mental conditions will probably feel extremely uncomfortable about discussing them because WELL MOVIES LIKE THIS. Using mental illnesses and the incredibly misinformed stereotypes surrounding them as a way to make money is just plain stupid, especially when a movie where these would be corrected would most likely create a much better, well, movie.Also, the movie made it look like she was able to control her transformations, which is ridiculous, it's not like an on/off-switch you press. It happens through triggers. And she seemed to be able to hide the other personality of hers which, once again is completely unrealistic.The ending was confusing and the point where she walks out of the hospital is in my opinion completely unnecessary. I doubt anyone liked that part simply because it was such an obvious "mysterious ending oooo". I would have been a lot less disappointed if the movie had ended when they met each other at the hospital -- at least that would've indicated that Grace got help for her untreated illness.

Another day in Lockdown and another film to watch, this time it is Deadly Illusions and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees an author hire a young babysitter to watch her children, when the two of them start to build a friendship and connection.Main Character
Kristin Davis of Sex and The City fame plays the lead character here and she is just not very good. Her character is really bland and uninteresting with Davis delivering some really cringe worthy dialogue that made her a character that never connected in any way shape or form.Supporting Characters
Greer Grammer plays the young girl that joins as the babysitter and she is also really bad here. She delivers line after line of awful dialogue and she just has some truly bad scenes that makes it hard for you to by anything in the film and the supposed chemistry between her and Davis which is never there. Dermot Mulroney plays Davis' husband in the film and he is literally just phoning it in and just playing the same character he does in every other project he is in. The rest of the cast offer nothing as well and the acting is just really bad.Story
Ever since Fatal Attraction was released, Hollywood has believed they can just churn out similar films for cheap with nothing unique and they are pretty much all bad and this one is no different. This film is laughably bad and throughout it does nothing interesting and then the last act happens and it is is just hilariously ridiculous and makes no sense.Script
The script is terrible, the dialogue is as mentioned above cringe. With drama, humour and romantic dialogue that are all terrible and the actors deliver it in such ways to make it seem even worse. Then someone wrote the ending of the film and they just had no clue what they were doing and maybe they should move into comedy.Style
The style of the film is awful, the pacing is so slow and literally nothing happens for ages and even when it does it is terrible. Plus this film is way too long, a film like this in 2021 should never be 2 hours long and it just keeps on going.Overall
Overall, this is a truly awful film. Deadly Illusions is one of the worst films of the year so far and is one that should never be seen by anybody.Rating - 1/10.

reviews.review_title: #1 Most Cringe-Worthy Movie on Netflix is the only list this movie should be on
reviews.content: This movie was so terrible on all levels imaginable. The acting was awful, and the script was even worse. The unraveling of what had supposedly happened just comes out abruptly without diving into any details properly. The movie does not understand itself, and the scenes seem put together without a second look at what works and what doesn't.

And I can't tear my eyes away from the hot mess on screen tearing out my eyeballs, I start to imagine a different script and perhaps the writer's intentions which somewhere along the line got chewed up by the dog or somesuch. So these are my thoughts. I don't think any of the savagery took place except in the author's imagination. Or the sex scenes between the two women. Speaking of sex, what I found alarmingly amusing was Dermot Mulroney diving under the sheets like a seal or a porpoise without one flicker of any kind of sexual excitement. Even the ending, which I won't get into here surely was in her imagination? This was telegraphed way back at the beginning when she talked about the "episodes" she has when she is writing her series of bestellers..And the acting was pitiful and the whole thing was very rushed. And the twins were so unequal in size as to lift the eyebrows a lot. Defo one of the worst of 2021 so far. Shame on you Netflix for throwing this garbage on our screens.

reviews.review_title: Oh! I see what they did there

There is the erotic storyline, where the babysitter seduces both the mother and the father which leads to jealousy. The second storyline is a Fight Club ripoff where the mother develops a side personality, the babysitter, because of stress and surpressed emotions. Third is just a story where they hire a babysitter who turns out to be nuts, maybe making it a murder mystery / slasher movieInstead of picking one storyline they decided to combine them all, because what could go wrong? The end result is an utter mess and one of the most frustrating movies I've ever seen. The plot and storytelling make absolutely no sense. reviews.review_title: If you enjoy classic thrillers, then this movie is for you.
reviews.content: Don't listen to the negative reviews. This movie is a thriller and exactly what it says on the tin. If you're expecting it to be something else, then you're wasting your time. Having said that, I enjoyed every bit of it. It was slow paced, character driven, tense and very well made. Yes it's corny and yes it's also trashy in parts too, but that's what makes a thriller a classic. There are some very raunchy parts too, which were not only pleasing to watch, but they added a 'forbidden fruit / Pandora's box' feel to the relationship between Mary and Grace. All of the negative reviews were clearly written by people expecting something completely different to what it actually is. Like I said if you are a fan of thrillers than this movie is for you.

reviews.review_title: In someone else's hands it could have been so much better
reviews.content: The story, had it been executed by an accomplished director, could have been amazing. My take on this is that Mary has an alter ego. All the books she has written before are violent and this perhaps is her outlet to remain *normal* on the outside. But since we are seeing everything from Mary's POV we have to ultimately conclude that there IS NO GRACE. Mary is Grace. Through creating this character, a younger version of Mary who possibly was abused as a child herself, she is able to break free from her writer's block and function as a person. The end scene is confusing. She is wearing the same headscarf and coat that was seen on footage of the woman who slashed the throat of Mary's best friend, Elaine. So who is that person leaving the hospital after visiting Grace? I am not sure why the director left us guessing like this. I am also uncomfortable when mental illness is used as a vector to spread disinformation about people who suffer mentally. In the 1960s there was a film TWISTED NERVE that had an insane man commit gross murders. But he happened to have a younger brother with Downs Syndrome. The film alluded to the fact that this murderer had a damaged gene in his family. And Downs Syndrome was the connection. This is lazy and sloppy. I think Deadly Illusions fell into the same trap. I would have liked to have seen an intelligent portrayal of a deeply disturbed woman.

Deadly Illusions review :First things first. The only reason I spent two hours of my life on this loophole laden and at times, utterly predictable erotic thriller was only for my fave 'Sex and The City' star Kristin Davis. She plays a middle age novelist going through a writers block and to devote more time on work, hires a young nanny (Greer Grammer) to look after the kids. Not long before she starts sexually fantasizing about her sweet new employee and worse, unable to differentiate if this lesbian liaison is indeed her dream or the real world. Intense, eh?!!..you may ask.Nah, on the contrary, Deadly Illusions is like those typical B movies of Hollywood watched largely for guilt pleasure than anything else. The plot is unreal, the twists are laden with glaring loopholes and the climax (or anti-climax if you could call it that) is a huge let down with some unanswered questions. To put it bluntly, the film just crumbles in the last fifteen minutes. Sad to say this as there was a good concept here which got mauled and killed by inept execution.As for the ever charming Kristin, her performance is the best of the lot and you will actually sit through this muddle of a movie only if you love her. Others can skip it safely!!Regards,
Sumeet Nadkarni.

reviews.review_title: Read it right after watching it...
reviews.content: It could have been a great movie if the director would helped the audience a bit more to understand what's going on. Well the key to understand is to realize that the writer becomes schizophrenic every time she starts a new book. Anything that happens after she starts to write is a confused mix of her entities. There is no real babysitter as such. It's herself, the mother who will not have enough time for her kids. That's why the babysitter is such a clean type, called Grace, her age sometimes 20 but sometimes 40. She also is the main character of her new book. Things get messy. Keys to understand are scattered around in the movie, but it just never becomes clear for most viewers. The note about her illness, the slit wheel, her visit to Grace's schizophrenic relative etc. It would have been a more helpful ending to understand, if at the end she would visited 'Grace', they would played cards but looking into the room we would only have seen Mary. Once you realize that it's her madly creative world your are watching the movie becomes quite a good film. If only the director helped us a bit more....

IN A NUTSHELL:
I was intrigued to watch this movie because I'm an author and author coach. The film's description says: After a bestselling novelist suffering from writer's block hires a new nanny for her children, the line between fiction and reality starts to blur. It's a psychological, erotic thriller that is so badly executed that I'm giving you fair warning here.THINGS I LIKED:
Fans of Sex and the City will be excited to see Kristin Davis starring in a feature film. Unfortunately, she's not a strong enough actress to save this film. Her character is conflicted in many ways. I thought it was sweet that, as a mom, she had different handshakes to say goodbye to each of her kids when she dropped them off at school.Greer Grammer stars in the movie and also produces it.I liked the original musical soundtrack by Drum & Lace.Every author's writing process is different. In the movie, we see Kristen Davis' character writing her book with pen and paper, rather than on a computer. I have some author clients who do that. We also see her create a storyboard on a big board, a technique I recommend to my clients because it really helps you "see" the story develop and allows you to be very intentional where you place certain scenes.Husbands and wives need to be extremely careful in order to protect their marriage from external relationships and impropriety. For example, my husband NEVER drove home our female babysitters. It wasn't that I didn't trust him or our sweet babysitters. Too many crazy things can happen based on what other people think could have happened, you know? It's just not worth it. No, people shouldn't assume or judge, yet they do.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
Even the title isn't original. So many books have been written with the same name.I'm surprised that Dermot Mulroney went for this script.Weird and creepy. I mean who takes a complete stranger bra shopping? That's the first scene when you realize the movie is ridiculous and it just gets worse.It's often hard to know what's really happening and what's fantasy. Of course, that's the point because the protagonist can't either. Then again, the execution and writing are so bad that it makes you wonder if the writer and director even knew.There are some really terrible acting moments.There's a terribly cliched flower moment.Lots of exposition.There are twists but they're ridiculous with so many details that don't make sense. We're left with more questions because Act 3 is a complete mess.There were some "Gollum" moments that made me laugh out loud. (The psycho hobbit in the Lord of the Rings)TIPS FOR PARENTS:
This movie is NOT appropriate for children. Plus, they'll be bored anyway.You see a married couple rolling around under the sheets. Then later, they do it in a kitchen closet.You see some skin when two best friends are in a spa sauna & shower.A pretty girl wears an immodest bathing suit. You see her in a bra many times.The mom smokes cigars as a symbol of her warped and developing manly obsessions of a young girl.A woman goes skinny dipping in the pool. Later, you see part of her naked chest in a bathtub.Tons of inappropriate sexual illusions.Two women kiss.You see some blood in a murder scene.Some profanity, crude language, and an F-bomb
You see the naked backside of a man in a shower
Violence.You can see my full review on my Movie Review Mom YouTube channel!

I'm really in no position to review this movie, as I still haven't seen the last 15 minutes. But, if that doesn't tell you all you need to know, then you need educating about film reviews...
For now, I'm going to assume the ending is predictable and lame. The first 1 hour and 45 minutes is, so I don't see why that would suddenly change.
In summary it's essentially a modern day remake of The Hand That Rocks The Cradle, an early 90's film that was good for its time. They've altered some aspects to modernise it, like make the live-in babysitters obsession with the mother become sexual, in addition to it being sexual with the husband. But otherwise it wanders no further from the hackneyed plot of "obsessed outsider infiltrates and ruins family".
It's one of those films that I think people in the industry still think they're right when they have meetings around tables and say things to each other like "We're gonna show people how wealthy this family is because people love seeing opulence!" When in actual fact that approach is dated and considered very unrelatable these days.
It kind of attempts to make you wonder whether the main female character or the babysitter character is the one causing the problems. But it just comes across as muddled and unclear. You get what might be flashbacks, might be memories, or visions from the main character of both herself and the babysitter doing terrible things, because apparently she "gets very dark" when she's writing... yawn. She gets so dark she randomly goes completely mental, dropping the f-bomb at the dining room table in front of her kids, after no hint whatsoever that she was about to lose the plot. And everyone reacts... as if it's fairly normal.
Sadly this film suffers far too much from those annoying experiences viewers have, such as saying to him/herself "You wouldn't do that / say that." Or "Why did she do / say that?" many times throughout the film.
Ultimately, it bears little resemblance to normal people and normal everyday life, which is a shame because it's a straight up drama based on earth in 2021...
Sometimes we wonder why such senseless movies are made!! Slow, boring, dull and what not! My recommendation is to save few hours instead of watching it !!

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst Movies I Have Watched
reviews.content: This movie has to be one of the worst I have ever watched. The plot itself sounded promising, but the execution is awful. First of all, both the acting and script are cringeworthy. The script contains dialogue that no one would say in real life. Next, the plot contains major holes. Grace's motivations for killing off the family are never revealed, besides the fact that she says she is "insane." Also, the children are absent for the majority of the movie when Grace was hired to be their caregiver. Lastly, my major bone to pick with this movie is its portrayal of DID, previously known as split personality. This movie further perpetuates the stereotypes associated with DID and continues to stigmatize the mental health disorder. The movie continues the harmful narrative that individuals with DID are "crazy" and prone to violent outbursts. In conclusion, not only does this movie contain terrible acting, cringeworthy dialogue, major plot holes, but it continues to demonize a real mental health disorder.
Don't waste your time with this not worth it. And you'll want to get your time back.

reviews.review_title: I don't give anything below a 2 star, unless it's this level of awful

While I was writing that I was thinking: "I haven't seen Music or Deadly Illusions, so maybe it's not the worst?" So, I gave one of these a try and immediately regretted it. This is far below a bad movie. This is an awful movie. The story has no clue what it wants to be. The acting is below mediocre. I laughed out loud multiple times about how bad the performances are. The dialog is not good. Its cliché stuff and so on the nose that it hurts. Also, the technical aspects are so annoying. Why are there so many cross-fades? And was the audio doing to this poor actress voice in the end? The only reasons I'm not going below a one star, is because it kept me mildly intrigued. It kept me interested enough to not turn it off. But that third act oh my god. The ending is so badly executed that I wanted to get drunk, so I could forget it as fast as possible. I still have so many questions. It's very hard not to spoil the ending, but why did this person go through all the trouble to get there? There is no reasoning at all. I'm going to watch Ted now just so I can wash away this mess of a movie.
I lasted 20 whole minutes. I'm wondering if anyone else lasted longer. 🙄

If you are hungry for entertainment while in proverbial Netflix & Chill mode, don't come here, you'll only be served an empty plate. No extravagance is spared with set, wardrobe, or vehicles, but script and acting falls flat onto its face in that mouse gray space between Lifetime Movie Network (with more nudity) and Cinemax After Hours (with less nudity). A slack, pathologically unimaginative, non-Hitchcockian snoozer of the lowest order. Greer Grammer fortunately doesn't take after her father in the looks department, as she is the only fresh, fetching face you'll find here; unfortunately she doesn't take after him in the acting department either. She seems overly surprised, like she was just goosed, in most scenes. Sapphic picnic in the dead, khaki weeds by a river. A punctured tire wheezes. Lazy framing. Why? An inconsequential child plays a quick flute solo and fails to propel the plot. San Francisco in a Santa Fe soap bubble? Several grotesque shots of a somnolent, snake-skinned Kristin Davis (who plays a monosyllabic writer?!) smoking cigars. Why? Speaking of gross, Shameless Dermot Mulroney (I'm constantly confusing him with Dylan McDermott, though the latter can act some) gets some impromptu, much needed liposuction in one of the unintentionally funnier scenes. There is no mystery, everything is telegraphed and spoiled early on. Like who didn't know the killer would be female after a good scissoring? Shanola Hampton (also of Shameless fame) is the only actor who decided to show up. At least she knows shoot from, well, Shinola! Netflix hits a new nadir. As the existentialists say, life really begins when you hit rock bottom. It's no illusion that this one was dead on arrival.

All in all, my point being, the movie was a refreshing break from mindless saturated action we see these days and far from a trash drama/thriller, which can be so pretentious.

I got fooled into watching this due to trending on Netflix. It turns out it's been shilled by promotors on tiktok. I knew this movie would suck immediately - the opening dialogue is the classic "we have no idea how to write a plot point" so they just have a character (that you never see again) say "You're *this person*, you're a writer, you sold out, you're a bad person because x/y/z..." At that moment I knew I was in trouble. It's amazing that a movie can be almost 2 hours long and lack any actual character development and avoid moving the story forward whatsoever. Here is the entire movie:
1. Movie opens and has a character explains who Kristin Davis is because they have no idea how to reveal it normally. 2. Husband "makes a bad trade" that you never know anything about and it's implied he loses half their money, though they are rich. You never see a lifestyle change or anything else come of this. This is revealed in a 2 minute scene on their patio and it's just over. 3. Kristin Davis has to write a new book now so she interviews nannies for a while until Greer Grammer shows up and gets the job. She spends the entire movie shopping and doing weird activities with the parents who never seem to spend any time with their kids. 4. Davis spends the whole movie telling everyone how "weird" she gets when she writes and you're not supposed to be able to tell if she's going crazy or if her affairs with Grammer are real or not. 5. Davis magically finds a family member of Greer two hours away and gets a dumb little traumatic backstory out of nowhere. 6. Davis' best friend is murdered, they think Davis did it but she can't be sure because she's sO cRaZy WhEn ShE WrItEs. 7. Greer is mentally ill and tries to murder the couple and locks the kids in a bedroom. 8. Davis wins the fight and Greer gets sent to an institution, but they're still friends and Davis visits her. Nothing. Interesting. Happens.

reviews.review_title: Quite a good film if somewhat campy
reviews.content:
I think many of the low reviews are a result of misunderstanding the film's point. On first viewing, the ending can be very frustrating. If time is spent thinking about the plot and perhaps with a second viewing (I know! I know!), I think more viewers would find much less fault with the film. There are a few hints throughout that point to a logical conclusion (or two).I believe the entire film is just Mary's book plot. We see evidence to support this theory. THis does not imply, however, that Mary is a well-adjusted author; she is not. Towards the Deadly Illusions ending, a close-up of Mary's storyboard with many things that happen in the film are noted. For example, her fight with Tom is mentioned there. The police officer also states that many events that have happened in real life are in her manuscript as well.When we learn Elaine is Mary's therapist, her notes say that Mary loses time and she's worried about her mental state. Elaine also comes to see Tom to talk to him about Mary's mental state. We also have various quotes from Elaine implying that "Grace" isn't real. Elaine's worrying about Tom's infidelity with "Grace" could easily be Mary projecting her fears of Tom being unfaithful with Elaine in her fantasy conversations with Elaine.Mary continues to lose grip with reality, resulting in her murdering Elaine and using the nefarious "Grace" from her novel to take the blame. Personally, I think It seemed way too easy for Mary to leave the police station, so I don't believe she did. I believe she's arrested for Elaine's murder, tried, and sent to a psychiatric ward.The best proof, I think, that the plot is novelized is the scene that plays out late in the film with Grace getting angry after applying for a job at the nanny agency, then we see a do-over with her being calm about the rejection. That's Mary rewriting the scene in real time. She decided the angry and cursing depiction didn't fit Grace's character, and, thus, rewrites the scene..
Mary admits, on more than one occasion, that she gets messed up while writing and often can't tell fact from fantasy. This phenomenon is what makes it so confusing to viewers. How are we expected to know when she doesn't know herself? If she were, indeed, hospitalized after her arrest for Elaine's murder, then everything that happens afterward is imaginary-> Mary and Grace have merged.

reviews.review_title: Leaves too much open to interpretation, thus losing the plot
reviews.content: Deadly Illusions starts off on a high note with Mary Morrison (Kristin Davis), a successful bestselling author looking for a caregiver for her two children while she reserves her time for a new novel, with a lucrative offer on the cards. She announces that when she writes, she transforms into someone she herself cannot control, and therefore without a nanny, her children will face neglect. Her husband Tom (Dermot Mulroney) is a busy executive too, and both are delighted with Grace (Greer Grammer), a young girl who opts for the job and is an instant hit with the kids.Grace however, is more than a handful as she starts to take control over the household, enters a passionate and steamy relationship with Mary and even seduces Tom. The sudden murder of Elaine, Mary's closest friend, suddenly wakes Mary out of her stupor as Grace is a suspect. Mary soon discovers that Grace wasn't sent by the agency she had contracted for hiring the nanny and that she is a known patient of split personality and bipolar disorder. In the meanwhile, Grace attacks Tom viciously at home and leaves him bleeding profusely. Mary is able to save Tom, but Grace is sent to a mental rehabilitation center that Mary visits often. She is also able to complete her new novel that she dedicates to Elaine, whose murder remains shrouded in mystery.Deadly Illusions meanders midway and loses direction completely before pressing the accelerator again towards the finishing line rather abruptly. It leaves many loose ends in need of being tied and also has a rather underwhelming climax, open to interpretation much more than anticipated. As such, it is a rather insipid outing with oodles of opportunities lost in the procedure. Performances are listless too, as no sympathy gathers for anyone concerned.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, until they throw it all away

What's utterly ridiculous is that up until this point, it does a really good job of hinting at a plot resolution and ending which would have been much, much better.It's like they switched writers for the last 10 pages of script.

reviews.review_title: Do not see this unless you are cleaning your house and it's just background noise
reviews.content: I just rejoined Netflix because after cancelling it after they didn't have anything new for like six months, I thought I'd give NF another try. It's not going well. Anyway, I see this flick with Kristin Davis and wondered if it was that awful one where her character's name was "Babette" (seriously) just to hear KD annoyingly say that name again. (KD has an annoying voice to me since I first saw her on MelrosePlace.) Then it started playing and I thought her character was going to be blind and when she wasn't blind I just figured I'd watch it and if it got too awful I'd turn it off. But I didn't, unfortunately.All the other 1/10 reviews are accurate and fair. This is just plain atrocious. I thought it was going to have at least some potential, I mean KD and Dermot have been in the biz for decades, at least we'd see some decent acting. So, KD is a very wealthy famous writer who accepts a book deal because her trading/gambling husband just lost half their money in a poor trade. But when she writes books, she goes crazy or something not developed or explained. So she needs a nanny. If you get to that part, turn it off. It's as bad as you can imagine after that, and really it didn't make sense. KD hires this nanny who literally just shows up at her doorstep after a day of KD interviewing potentials from some agency. She hires her on the spot WITHOUT contacting the agency to find out more about her. Why would a very wealthy famous person with a husband and two kids not at least run a background check on her??? Anyway, this young woman is beautiful, and I was immediately getting lesbian vibes. Great, this will be a twist on THTRTCradle, possibly interesting. But... KD just hired her and is kind of crushing on her, and she takes her to some ladies store and is helping her pick out bras. Maybe I am totally clueless about women, and I think I'm tuned, but do women, especially a boss and her new young employee help each other put on bras that fasten in the FRONT??? I kind of thought that you would try on the bra YOURSELF to see if it fastens quickly/easily? And this wasn't even her best friend since childhood, so they weren't exactly "sister from another mister" level in their relationship. Anyway, it just gets weirder and weirder with the sexual stuff. Then of course this nubile young woman predictably seduces the husband, keeps drugging KD it appears, and then KD's actual bestie gets murdered. And the police already know that it's a slam dunk case against KD before they even question her. God I hate these movies where the cops act like this... and her husband is a tool and DOUBTS her. Uggh. And quel surprise we find out that it is, shocker, the NANNY that is crazy af. At the END. When she slashes the husband and tries to kill KD. And this whole movie KD is working on her new novel where her publishers wanted her to go in "a different direction" anyway, so I figured we'd get a final scene where KD's resumed writing career gets a major resurgence, but nope. She has a manuscript entitled "Untitled" or "Unnecessary" that she dedicates to Elaine her bestie. But the worst is, the final scene is KD actually VISITING this psycho in the hospital and hugs on her and plays cards with her and then walks out of the hospital. What in the actual heck? It made no sense.Really, don't waste your time. And this is like the 20th Netflix stinker I've seen, I just don't understand why these craptastic movies are given the green light. They are awful, but not even in a funny, campy way. A waste of time.I at least.

A reasonably happy family with twins has need of a nanny so that the protagonist Mary writes a fresh novel to compensate the financial loss by her husband Tom.Grace, the babysitter has been liked by the twins, Tom suggests his wife to make her part of the family, Mary agrees.The audience watches Grace seducing both Mary and Tom separately ; it is harmless until the anniversary day of marriage.The so called dangerous illusions are revealed when Elain, a friend of Mary who watched Tom and Grace together and tried to warn Mary about that is found killed with scissors having fingerprints of her to make her the prime suspect; Mary inquires into background of Grace to find that she has history of being abused, reaches home to face climax with Grace who , apparently taken over by her another personality, namely, Margaret stabbed her husband. Margaret and Mary fight, and Mary defends herself by hitting Margaret over the head with a flower pot.The poignant dialogue is spoken by Grace,about Margaret, her evil half ,she says 'I couldn't stop her'.As a psycho sexual comedy the movie may be watched, there is no deep impact except eroticism between the husband, wife and the babysitter.

reviews.review_title: At least half an hour too long
reviews.content: This movie isn't different from any other cheap, Lifetimesque thriller Netflix offers. Bad script, mediocre acting, gaping plotholes... We got the full package; but truth be told, we saw it coming from a mile away. What I can't forgive is the length: almost two hours of my life just so the director could show me a a collection of supposedly "erotic" (and in reality really lame) scenes? What a waste.

Wow, where to begin...A truly awful script, with dialogue that must, surely have been written by a young child. People just don't talk, or behave like this, except possibly in low-end pornos. If that were not enough, the editing is shocking: Long lingering shots of various oceans, lakes and water features make me suspect the editor is a nostalgic sailor. Then there is the use of just about every clichè in the book. You really don't need to see this movie - you've already seen it, but better versions of it. If it has one saving grace (see what I did there?) it is that everyone in your lounge will look at each other periodically in confusion and say "What???" which is actually a bonding experience. If you do choose to watch it, do so quite drunk and maybe you can interpret this rambling mess as some kind of twisted black comedy. If so, I wish you good luck.

reviews.review_title: Everyone sleeps with the Nanny and it doesn't work out.

I read the reviews people have left for this movie and I have to say that I think they may be a bit too harsh.Yeah, it's a bad film but I've seen worse, by a long shot (anything by The Asylum films, for example).Still, it was pretty bad. I didn't have much of an expectation going in. I mean Kristin Davis isn't an A-list actress and I'm not a big fan of Dermot Mulroney.Hopefully Greer Grammer will recover from this experience and move on to something a little more meaningful. She did a decent job portraying a seductive nanny.I couldn't buy Kristin Davis as an author and found all of her 'writing' scenes to be silly and contrived. I have no idea what Dermot's daytime job was but he seemed serious about it.That scene at the end was just stupid. Suddenly, Grace is a 10-year-old playing crazy eights? And what mental health facility would have electric outlets without those silly plastic safety covers?And are we supposed to imagine that Grace was the one walking out with the headscarf at the end?

reviews.review_title: Three Stars For Three Lost Plots
reviews.content: There are parts of three different movies here. The writer could be imagining all this stuff in her mind before it makes it to papers. That is a clean and boring movie and it we had had transitions showing her mind separating from reality it would not be a bad movie, just a boring one.The insane murderous nanny is another plot line hinted at in movie trailers and Grace is charming enough that possibly she could pull it off, but again the transitions and editing do not really deliver that theme through to the end.The last plot line included in this Deadly Illusion movie is usually one of my favorites that being the classic just who's reality are the characters living and acting within. And there is just not enough of the characters paths to discovering which reality is the one they are in here to warrant other than the star above.This is not as bad as the one and two star reviewers imply as we get a story told with care and intent--it is just not told well enough to follow. BUT this is not a good movie by any means no matter how it is being hyped and promoted as the trailer is all you really need to watch and then let your imagination run wild--that would be more rewarding.It is hip to include hinted at or actual lesbian scenes now so that is one more way to interpret this movie as a movie made to check off obligatory boxes in what one considers essential to a movie line. And if so, at least make it believable next time.Another way to review the movie is the stuff filmed in Albuquerque was awesome three stars for that setting and then zero for plot, acting, and compelling characters.

reviews.review_title: Why did these actors do this project?
reviews.content: This is a miserable failure. The only two reasons I think Dulmot Mulroney. Kristin Davis and Shanola Hampton would have ever done this is either they loved the idea of duality in horror (who doesn't?) or they made some pact with the devil in exchange for their talents. The script was really bad. I knew right away it was not going to be a solid pick, since the pacing almost felt like a Lifetime holiday film on a bad acid trip. The three listed above did their best with what they were given, especially Mulroney, but man, the direction and those horrible lines! Not to mention the plot holes were crater-sized and many of the characters' actions were implausible to anyone with common sense...and I have quite an imagination and can still not see anything like this going down in any circumstances. What was with the bra shopping? "Oh, hi, I am your brand new boss, but I am going to take you bra shopping and GO IN THE DRESSING ROOM WITH YOU." Such a natural unfolding of events we have all experienced at sometime, amirite? Some other highlights include twin kids that look completely different ages, horrible acting by some secondary actors, a psychiatric disorder many doctors deny exist and a storyline that defies logic in any universe. I mean, where did the extra bike come from? If she "hadn't done this in a long time" (as in, riding a bike), why did she have a brand new adult bike just sitting around ready for them to go on a long, sensual ride to the lake (where they had a full spread with wine yet no character was seen going or coming back with any supplies)? It's little things like that, over and over again that just makes the viewer wish they had bowel problems so they could take a bathroom break to avoid another scene. Just don't watch it. It will make you depressed that actors like these are taking on projects like this. I was debating a 1, but gave it a 2 since you do get to see Mulroney's bare ass and that is never disagreeable as far as I am concerned. But someone's going to be up for a Razzie for this excrement and it will be well deserved. I wish Netflix refunded money for things they say are "#3 watched in the nation" but suck this bad. It's uncool to set viewers up like that.

reviews.review_title: Really not that bad! Worth a watch
reviews.content: Overly critical reviews here - I thought it was clever, suspenseful and worth watching. *Spoiler alert* here:I thought the reveal of Grace's (or now Margaret's) split personality explained the different sides we were seeing throughout the movie; we were actually led to think that Mary was either imagining the "naughty" side or going through a mental break caused by the story she was writing, when in reality, we were seeing the story through Grace or Margaret. I also think the cinematography, angles, sort of cheesy mystery undertones were intentional and nostalgic.Watch it, it was entertaining - and don't listen to people here who didn't quite get it and rushed to judgement.

At first I actually enjoyed the feeling of this more 90s thriller style but quickly I was bored by the lack of depth and obvious plot line. There was no real twist at all and I am fine with this when the rest is well made and played but this was not the case here.All characters were pretty stereotypical which worked actually for the surficial setting but when it came to the "reason" Grace's actions, I was disgusted. This is nothing against the actress but how the producer chose to display "mental illness and/or trauma" in a "haunted shizophreniac" way. It was also not well executed in my eyes but the major issue I have is the framing and not the execution. The creepy voice over was just the overkill and made me actually chuckle cause the whole movie all of a sudden felt more like a comedy with slight "scary movie" style.So overall I think there can be charme with this type of movies in 2021, as hommage to the evil nanny, what is real what is illusion genre, but sadly not in this case.

I can say a lot more negative things about this, but I don't consider myself a big film critic so I won't. I will say, however, that the show falls into a trope that I truly can't stand. It seems like every poor Netflix psychological thriller has the same twist; "omg they had multiple personalities, who would've guessed?" Everyone. Everyone has seen this trope before and, with no surprise at all, Netflix is pioneering in this lazy, unthoughtful and incorrect twist. The babysitter of the film, Grace, is the one who is supposed to have this mental illness, it's a shame that it was done so lazily.Warning: if you watch multiple movies like this you will receive a never ending headache. This is the show you watch when you cannot find an interesting title. This is also the type of movie you watch in 20 minutes because your hand is always placed directly above the skip button (though, to my regret, I did sadly sit through this entire movie for the sheer pleasure of writing this review). Not a fan.

reviews.review_title: Adds nothing to a saturated genre
reviews.content: Contains spoilers. But trust me, you won't care. This movie is so predictable even from the trailer it feels impossible to spoil.This is just another in a long line of 'crazy babysitter attempts to usurp family and gaslights mother', but done extremely poorly. If you are going to take on a saturated genre, it needs to be fresh and/or brilliant. This film is neither. Greer Grammer in no way has the acting chops to pull off a character with DID and the climax will make you roll your eyes instead of quiver with fear, and don't get me started on the clumsy and blink and you'll miss it handling of mental illness.It's slim pickings content wise due to COVID and we are left with garbage like this unfortunately, but do yourself a favour and rewatch Orphan or The Hand That Rocks The Cradle instead if you are a fan of the genre and have a couple hours to kill. This isn't even 'bad good'.

It's around here where the acting really starts to drop off as well, it turns from a Riverdale quality film to a 2002 Disney channel, straight-to-TV quality film. The more absurd the plot gets they more the actors seem to with draw from their roles, like they really just don't care about putting the effort in anymore. The main actresses performances in particular go from good to desperately bad. From an action point no of the hits have impact, even the really violent scene are just so uneventful and you don't have much reason to care for the characters.In the end, the exploitative portrayal of dissociative identity disorder and the inclusion of a child abuse plot, which closely resembles the Turpin case to an uncomfortable degree, were the final nail in the coffin for this film. I can't believe they tried to hint a sequel at the end.

All those 1 star reviews must be contagious to others who rate it similarly, as if to hide the fact that they induged in watching it and feel guilty getting their cheap thrills. I've seen worse movies and just click away without needing to rate it up or down. It wasn't just a formula film, it wasn't from Sundance but it is good. Just the very, very bad babysitter genre, one thinks, yet that's merely the surface framework. The writer stresses out over competing priorities when she has to work. Hence, her strong reluctance to consider writing again and refusal of book deal offers. She's really into to raising her kids, enjoying her wonderful family wants to put all that first. Unexpected occurrences lead her to cave-in to the pushy publishing agents and accept new work. The psychological hell of all the suspicions and doubts about hiring the perfect and pretty young nanny begin to arise. The low reveiwers, (not unlike anyone who falls unawares into mentally troubled waters) are titalated yet frustrated, just don't follow the pure, wordless dipiction of descent into mental illness. So one star givers, Get over it. And the film is perfectly fine for what it is, easy on the eyes, not escapist fare. An enjoyable, though predictable film that one should watch knowing that stylistically it's very, very obtuse, which isn't going to gain great acclaim. Not typical hollywood, but along with nice sets, great cinematography it's fine to spend an hour with if you're not doing anything else. All those one star reviews are hysterical lcopy cats or maybe work for a competing film studio. They're totally unwarranted. I'm only adding a review to counter the others that seem hysterically idiotic.I'e.

reviews.review_title: SPOILERS AHEAD also don't waste your time
reviews.content:
All this movie does is stigmatize people with DID as dangerous and unpredictable, and people to be feared. It's 2021, have we not had enough of generalized cliche thrillers based on very real illnesses people deal with in real life??There is nothing unique about this movie besides the super creepy dynamic between Mary and Grace, meanwhile Grace and the husband (forgot his name) also having an affair??
The movie creators could have easily just made grace a manipulative killer, not someone with multiple personalities talking to herself back and forth with an evil personality that want to kill them. It's ungodly cringey and probably offensive to people. (That's not how DID works btw but sure let's just add to the stigma and misunderstanding of the disorder all together) Not only did they make Grace a character with DID, but for some reason also her aunt too?? Ok??Literally the only thing it adds to the plot is when Mary goes to visit her in a psychiatric facility, out of pity I presume. Only to be murdered and stripped of her clothing so Grace can wear them out of the building and escape. Which if the producer's were absolutely NEEDING that to be the end of the movie and couldn't possibly have it any other way, it could've easily been done without her having multiple personalities.In conclusion: Stupid, Boring, Uncomfortable Sexual Dynamic, Cliche, Slightly Offensive, and Poorly Done

The movie made no sense whatsoever, which sucks considering I had high hopes for it based on the Title. I was expecting something like a lifetime movie, but that's not what I got at all. I kept waiting for this movie to be good and make sense but it never did. All I gathered from this crap is that a wife with 2 kids hires a nanny so she can write a novel. She begins to have lesbian fantasies about the nanny, and it's really hard to tell if she is fantasizing or if it's really happening. That's all this movie was about, a woman having fantasies about her nanny. The title of the movie doesn't fit at all! I thought it was going to be about a psycho nanny, but boy was I wrong.
This is the worst film I've ever seen in my life. Boring, no sense, poor acting. Why Netflix, why?

When René Magritte stated that the pipe in his painting was in fact not one, the viewer was pushed to ask themselves some questions. Perhaps the artist was saying that it not a pipe because it is a painting of one? Or, maybe Magritte was asking us to question our own understanding of things?This film was like that. It surely can't be a film about a childcare worker, a wealthy family, a writer, etc., because it is just too bad for that. How else could you account for the fact that the music, writing, acting and cinematography were all so perfectly and symmetrically horrible? There must be something else going on.I asked myself these questions about this movie, and continue to, because it is just too awful. There must be something else going on. There must be.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as the sheep think....
reviews.content: People love to bash everything these days and movies are just another thing people like to seem clever about. This film by no means is an academy award winner but it is entertaining and fun in its short comings. It's a straight to Netflix film, what did you expect??!! The only real problem with this film is the fact that it's so over the top at times you start to believe the main character is actually writing the events taking place in her new writing project. When you realize it's actually what's taking place, that is when your let down but in a very fun "made for TV movie" kind of way. If you like smutty films this one is excellent and does not disappoint. Kristen David looks amazing and the Nanny does a great job creating steamy action. All in all enjoyed this film except for the fact that it could have been so much more if the writers actually believed in what they were making!! Fun watch.... enjoy!! Forget the haters!!

The husband then gets attacked in the shower but Mary runs around and doesn't think it best to check on her own kids. Don't watch this film!!
